subject: Learning
title: Brown v Board of Education
description: Learn Brown v Board of Education in one minute.

hook.text: In 1954, the US Supreme Court said separate schools for Black and white children were inherently unequal.

buildup.text: For decades, 'separate but equal' justified segregated schools with wildly unequal resources.

discovery.text: Brown v Board of Education ruled unanimously that segregation violated the Equal Protection Clause.

twist.text: The ruling changed the law but not the reality. Desegregation was resisted for decades.

climax.text: Even today, school funding often correlates with neighborhood wealth, creating de facto segregation.

punchline.text: The law changed in 1954. The work of equality continues.

quiz.question: What did Brown v Board of Education rule?
options: Separate schools for different races are inherently unequal
Segregated schools are acceptable if equally funded
